definition:
Let $G \subset {\mathbb{C}}$ be a domain.

Let $f \colon G \to {\mathbb{C}}$ be a meromorphic function, then the
[*spherical derivative*]{} of $f$, denoted $f^\sharp$ is defined as
$$f^\sharp(z) := \frac{2\lvert f'(z) \rvert}{1+\lvert f(z) \rvert^2}$$
for $z$ where $f(z) \not= \infty$ and when $f(z) = \infty$ define
$$f^\sharp(z) = \lim_{\zeta \to z} f^\sharp(\zeta) .$$

The second definition makes sense since a meromorphic functions has only
isolated poles, and thus $f^\sharp(\zeta)$ is defined by the first
equation when we are close to $z$. Some basic properties of the
spherical derivative are as follows.

If $f \colon G \to {\mathbb{C}}$ is a meromorphic function then

-   $f^\sharp$ is a continuous function,

-   $f^\sharp(z) < \infty$ for all $z \in G$.

Note that sometimes the spherical derivative is also denoted as
$\mu(f)(z)$ rather then $f^\sharp(z)$.
